item.title: Sesame Workshop CEO: PBS cuts not ‘existential threat’
item.description: Still, Sherrie Westin, the CEO of Sesame Workshop, said the nonprofit’s partnership with PBS is crucial.

item.title: Investors await Paramount’s next bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: CEO David Zaslav and his board rejected an initial bid of roughly $20 per share.

item.title: Suitors pick over Warner Bros. Discovery’s assets
item.description: Comcast and Paramount are among potential bidders as the CNN parent runs a sale process.

item.title: Zaslav stands to make $500M from Warner Bros. Discovery sale
item.description: Zaslav has long been one of media’s best-paid CEOs despite shareholder returns that lag larger rivals.

item.title: The inside story of Sydney Sweeney’s ‘great jeans’ — and why American Eagle ignored crisis comms
item.description: American Eagle’s campaign with Sydney Sweeney blew up in ways no one could’ve imagined – but CMO Craig Brommers knew they were going to hit a cultural nerve.

item.title: News consumption habits split US, study finds
item.description: More than four in 10 voters are “passive” news consumers, meaning they let information come to them, according to Global Strategy Group.

item.title: CBS’ Weiss explores poaching conservatives from other networks
item.description: CNN personality Scott Jennings visited the new CBS News editor-in-chief, Bari Weiss, this week at CBS’ New York headquarters.

item.title: CPB hits back against NPR in court
item.description: The nearly-defunct federal Corporation for Public Broadcasting sought summary judgment in NPR’s lawsuit against the organization over its decision to appropriate funding for satellite distribution to a select group of NPR member stations.

item.title: Shapiro-Carlson spat over Gaza highlights deepening rift on the right
item.description: Commentator Ben Shapiro has told at least one person privately that he had planned to denounce Tucker Carlson in a speech at a Turning Points USA event before Charlie Kirk was shot.

item.title: Data journalists start news site to track extremist movements
item.description: Decoherence Media is a new digital publication covering “authoritarian and anti-democratic movements, with a particular focus on the far-right,” co-founder Tristan Lee told Semafor.

item.title: Right-wing influencers post. Federal force follows.
item.description: The White House is increasingly attentive to the concerns of personalities like Nick Shirley.

item.title: British newspaper spoke to the wrong de Blasio, not an ‘imposter’
item.description: How a Long Island vintner, with the help of ChatGPT, prompted a transatlantic journalistic debacle.

item.title: The AI boom is turning old content into cash cows for creators
item.description: A handful of creators have been paid more than $1 million to license their videos to AI companies.

item.title: Ken Burns on the future of PBS, the new age of media, and why documentaries will outlast TikTok
item.description: Ken Burns has been telling the story of America through his entire career with genre-defining documentaries on the Civil War, the Vietnam War, and now the American Revolution.

item.title: Trump to sit with CBS News in first interview after lawsuit
item.description: The US president is set to sit down with CBS anchor Norah O’Donnell on Friday afternoon, Semafor has learned.

item.title: The new Vanity Fair’s one rule: Leave the princesses alone!
item.description: Vanity Fair is trying to offer meaningful journalism that reveals inner workings of power — while also convincing the powerful to pose for its covers and attend its Hollywood events.

item.title: Can anyone stop Tucker Carlson?
item.description: The uproar over his interview with Nick Fuentes only seemed to boost his profile.

item.title: Wikipedia founder says ‘Gaza genocide’ page lacked neutrality
item.description: The publicly editable nature of Wikipedia makes it a battleground, with entires often becoming viewed as established fact.
